title: The Cause Of Sorrow
opening: Things take a turn for the worse as you and Jeralt investigate an abandoned chapel in Garreg Mach.

intro.speaker: Alois
intro.line: Captain? Captain! Where are you? Hey, Professor. Have you seen your old man?

intro.speaker: Alois
intro.line: Too bad. I guess it will have to be you, then...

intro.speaker: Jeralt
intro.line: I'm back. Sorry for the delay, my last mission took longer than expected.

intro.speaker: Alois
intro.line: Captain! Thank goodness you're here. There are reports of Demonic Beasts near the chapel!

intro.speaker: Jeralt
intro.line: Nonsense. I haven't heard anything about the monastery's walls being breached.

intro.speaker: Alois
intro.line: That's why I'm heading there now, to see what's really going on. You'll join as well, won't you?

intro.speaker: Jeralt
intro.line: Of course. We're both sworn to protect this place.

intro.speaker: Alois
intro.line: It's odd. Just before they appeared, someone saw a number of students heading toward the chapel. They were apparently acting strange, as though they weren't in their right minds. Shortly after, Demonic Beasts started to appear, one after the other.

intro.speaker: Jeralt
intro.line: Hm... The students... There's no way those Demonic Beasts got in from the outside... But none of that matters right now. We need to act. Go summon your students.

intro.speaker: Jeralt
intro.line: Damn it... I wanted to talk to you about something important, but there's no time. There's never any damn time. But this is much more urgent, so it can hold for now. I'll meet you there.

conversation.speaker: Sothis
conversation.line: Tomas... No, Solon, was it not? And the Flame Emperor... It is most clear that something has transpired. And it relates to you somehow. Or is the fault my own, and you're just caught inside the wave... Sothis, the goddess of this world... I bear her name... Hmm... How confusing. I feel as though my head has turned to mush!

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: Everyone's in such a festive mood. I feel a bit out of my element here. I can't help but worry something might happen while we're all distracted... After all, our enemies are always plotting. Still, this air of levity is much more agreeable than the grim atmosphere of late.

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: It seems the dastards who set Remire Village aflame have yet to be apprehended. Monsters. Trampling mercilessly over innocent lives. They deserve a gruesome end...

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: Someone entered the old chapel... I think the townsfolk used it for feasts and such in the past. With that whole Tomas business, you can't blame the church for being on edge.

conversation.speaker: Hubert
conversation.line: Another month full of chaos. I've barely had time to catch my breath. What is the objective of Tomas and his ilk? And what makes Flayn so special–does that not bother you?

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: Ah, the ball. It reminds me of my first such event, back in the Imperial capital. It was held by my father, the prime minister. I really showed off my dancing skills! Everyone was quite impressed with me.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: You know, Professor, I used to think I would be comfortable with all manner of experiments, so long as they provided usable results. But when I heard of Solon's work, well, I realized I'd not consider the moral and philosophical limits of what "all manner of experiments" might mean. Urk... Sorry. I'm not great with blood, even when I'm just thinking about it. I feel a bit ill now.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: I can't believe this... I'm so angry right now! First it's the Death Knight, and now Tomas, and neither of them are in custody! I can't stand the thought of such evil lurking in the world. We have to do something about this! I have to do something about this!

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: The ball. A grim reminder of my sad reality. The other nobles will be fine, I'm sure. They've all been to events like this before. But me? I'm a noble, and I've never even been close to one of these things!

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: I wonder if Remire Village will ever be the same again. How do you recover from such a terrible event? So many dead, so much destroyed... I can't see how the whole village doesn't just end up abandoned.

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: Our class was also sent to help put the village in order. But then…

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: Dancing of Fódlan is not the same as dancing of Brigid. The reason is maybe that the music has many differences. In Brigid, dancing is different for each person. Our dancing has vigor and ferocity. There is no speech of technique for our dancing.

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: Even though there is to be a ball, we still have a mission. It would be nice if this month passed by in peace.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: Argh... Too much merriment. The librarian betrayed us. The Death Knight is back. Is this the time to be throwing a ball?

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: Last month was– Well, you know even better than I do. I hope this one will be more cheerful. This ball though... I don't know. It's all new to me.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Great work in Remire Village, Professor. Who would have ever guessed it was Tomas? Ah, but no. Now isn't the time to get lost in gloomy thoughts.

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: Oh, now, where did that Ingrid run off to? The ball is soon and she hadn't even put on any makeup! I was trying to help her out.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: So, Tomas the librarian was a bad guy? But he always seemed so nice! C'mon, self. You're better than this. You promised you'd be on top of things this month.

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Mercedes locked me in her room for hours earlier... She was slathering pounds of makeup onto my face. Saying something or other about the ball. It really wore me out...

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: Ah. The long-awaited ball. Finally, an opportunity to showcase my exquisite skills on the dance floor. These skills were ingrained in me when I was a boy. My hands and feet move on pure instinct.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: The ball is coming up soon! I am so excited! I can't wait to fill up on food while everyone's dancing. I even heard there'll be some prime cuts of meat!

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: Some scary things have been happening lately. I hope that this month, of all months, is peaceful. The ball is coming up and everything... Although I'm not much of a dancer actually.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: It's true that Tomas was employed here under the recommendation of House Ordelia. But that's all I know of the topic. I'd never even seen him prior to enrolling here. Even when he was supposedly in Ordelia territory, I never once saw him there. I'm still feeling bothered by all of this, but...there's not much else I can say about it right now.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: A ball? Um, I don't think I'll partake.

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: It's almost time for the ball! Oooh my, am I excited! This being a school, we don't have many chances to get dressy.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: I'm glad the Remire Village situation got sorted out. But it's not over yet, is it? And I can't believe old Tomas turned out to be an enemy. Who can you trust anymore?

conversation.speaker: Rhea
conversation.line: Before the ball, it is customary that we host a competition of dance known as the White Heron Cup. The students are quite fond of this tradition. Each house must select representatives to compete. Their dance shall be judged by its beauty, grace, and technique. The student who is deemed the winner will be given the opportunity to train as a dancer, should they so please. It is a very precious thing, the gift of dance. I hope that you and your students will choose to participate.

conversation.speaker: Rhea
conversation.line: I have been told that your house won the White Heron Cup. This can only be a result of the students' talent and effort, not to mention your steadfast instruction.

conversation.speaker: Rhea
conversation.line: It would appear your house was defeated in the White Heron Cup. With the White Heron Cup concluded, all that is left is to wait for the ball. I hope you will find it enjoyable.

conversation.speaker: Rhea
conversation.line: It has come to my attention that you did not participate in the White Heron Cup. Were none of your students skilled in dance? With the White Heron Cup concluded, all that is left is to wait for the ball. I hope you will find it enjoyable.

conversation.speaker: Seteth
conversation.line: I have looked into Tomas, but I just cannot make sense of this at all. From his behavior up until now, I never would have suspected that a man like him could turn on us. I have also discovered that his appearance has changed... It is almost as if he is not even human! What in the world is going on?

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: Hello Professor! The ball will soon be upon us. Ah, I can feel my heart fluttering already! I... I have never danced in front of people before. Not even once in all my life. I am very much looking forward to it!

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: Ah, the ball... It reminds me of how I met my wife. I was at a village's harvest festival. There was a full moon bathing everything in its cool glow. She appeared out of nowhere, dancing gracefully in the moonlight–a lovely fairy!

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That story sounds fake.

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: Hah! The "full moon" was an embellishment, I admit. But you can forgive a man for waxing poetic, can't you? Anyway...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: That's a wonderful story.

conversation.speaker: Alois
conversation.line: We soon fell in love and tied the knot. Now we have a daughter, who's as bright and beautiful as a sunny morning. So, whenever I see people dancing, I think of my wife, and my heart does a little waltz.

conversation.speaker: Catherine
conversation.line: The area with the old chapel was supposed to be off-limits. It was at risk of collapse, so they didn't even post guards. It's not too strange. Does that surprise you? Eh, Garreg Mach has lots of places that are blocked off for one reason or another. That's true of the underground Holy Mausoleum as well as the northern woods. People call it the sealed forest, but as far as I can tell, it's nothing special. Just a forest.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: What's this about? The ball? Knights don't participate. It's an event for students, but it does pique the interest of some knights in particular.

conversation.speaker: Shamir
conversation.line: Alois can't dance, but I hear he likes to watch. He volunteered to judge the White Heron Cup. Not that I care.

conversation.speaker: Gilbert
conversation.line: It cannot be true that our siblings-in-arms could turn against us. However, I will continue investigating members of the church. To think even someone as senior as Tomas would fall under suspicion... I know not how far to take my search.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Even the knights...

conversation.speaker: Gilbert
conversation.line: Unlike the monks, the Knights of Seiros are Lady Rhea's direct subordinates. Some are in quite unique circumstances, but I cannot think any of them would betray us.

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: Even the students...

conversation.speaker: Gilbert
conversation.line: Yes, a great many strange and terrible things have come to pass this year... I must not dismiss the possibility that someone among the students is behind it all.

conversation.speaker: Hanneman
conversation.line: Garreg Mach Monastery is said to have been completed during the Ethereal Moon. Why, 995 years ago as a matter of fact. That's rather a long time ago, don't you think? Every year, a ball is held to celebrate the founding. And every one hundred years, a very special celebration takes place. It's a grand festival, involving all of Garreg Mach. It is thrilling to read of past festivals, and I'm rather excited to experience one for myself. Once in a lifetime, eh? The next one, in five years, will make a millennium. Should be quite an event. Do you imagine you'll still be here teaching then?

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: Great. Just...great. It's that time when all the students get all lovey-dovey. You're new, but you know about the ball, yeah? I can't bear it. Young love is wasted on the young. They can't appreciate it to its fullest! Ugh, I wish I could fall in love too...

conversation.speaker: Manuela
conversation.line: Oh! Speaking of the ball, Professor, have you selected your representative for the dance contest yet? If you don't, the contest will go on without your house. And that would be...embarrassing.

conversation.speaker: Cyril
conversation.line: Nah, Tomas wouldn't betray the church. I don't believe it. I won't believe it! There's some people in the church who hate people like me who are from Almyra, but Tomas was always real kind. But if he really was Lady Rhea's enemy... Well, I'd defend her against anybody. No matter how kind they'd been in the past.

conversation.speaker: Anna
conversation.line: Hey, Professor. How's it going? Making lots of coin? I'd love to catch up, but I'm super busy right now. Working. For money. You understand.

conversation.speaker: Gatekeeper
conversation.line: Greetings, Professor! Nothing to report! Ah, other than the legend of the Goddess Tower, of course. Have you heard the students talking about it? On the last night of the Ethereal Moon, on the same night as the ball... If a man and a woman go to the Goddess Tower and make a wish, it's sure to come true! I have a wish, but I can't find anybody to make it with me...

conversation.speaker: Byleth
conversation.line: (Is there someone I feel that way about?)

conversation.speaker: Rhea
conversation.line: The White Heron Cup is a competition of skill and grace in dance. Please encourage your house to participate. That said, if you are serious about winning, be sure to choose your representative carefully.

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: By the way, have you chosen our house's representative for the White Heron Cup? If nobody else comes to mind, I'm willing to take up the challenge, Professor.

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: Understood. Just leave this to me and victory is assured.

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: I see... If you believe there's someone more qualified, I certainly won't object.

conversation.speaker: Hubert
conversation.line: On a lighter note. I've heard you've yet to choose a class representative for the White Heron Cup. It's not something I'm interested in, but if no one else wants to do it, then I will shoulder the burden.

conversation.speaker: Hubert
conversation.line: How very whimsical of you. I suppose I'll have to do what I can.

conversation.speaker: Hubert
conversation.line: Wise. Better to choose someone with more charm.

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: Do you see what I am trying to say here? Do not make me beg you... Please, choose me as our representative for the White Heron Cup!

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: Wonderful! You will have a chance to see the legendary footwork of House Aegir!

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: Hmph. If you really think someone is better suited for it, I will not argue.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: Let us change the subject and settle my stomach. I assume you've heard about the dance competition? Have you chosen a representative yet? Or... Oh my. You haven't, have you? Have you come to tell me I'm to be it?

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: I see... I can dance, in theory, but I dare say in practice things may go very differently.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: I think that's wise. I simply can't really be bothe-- What I mean to say is I lack the confidence.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: Ugh. Sorry about that, Professor. I'm just so frustrated right now. I need something to take my mind off things. That reminds me! If you're looking for a volunteer, I'd be happy to represent our class in the White Heron Cup. I'm an excellent Dancer.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: Great! We both know I'm our class's best chance at winning this thing.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: You really think you can find a better dancer than me?

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: What is a White Heron Cup, anyway? Wh-what?! A dance competition?! That's terrifying! W-we need a representative for our class?! Please, anyone but Bernie!

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: You're just trying to humiliate me, aren't you?

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: Oh, what a relief! Thank you so much, Professor!

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: I'm sorry, Professor. I'm talking about such grim and terrible things when we could be talking about the White Heron Cup. It's a big dance contest between the classes, and I simply adore dancing. I'm quite good at it, since I was a diva in an opera company, you know.

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: I think my heart just skipped a beat. You want me to represent the class? I'm not sure when I last experienced such flattery, Professor.

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: What? Why not me? Oh, whatever. So long as you remember to chose someone, hm?

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: Are you choosing me to represent at the White Heron Cup? Or are you not?

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: I will display all that I have learned. I will grab the victory!

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: I have understanding. You believe that I cannot grab the victory, I am guessing?

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: I... I'm sorry. Please ignore my troubled ramblings. Was something the matter? Something to do with the White Heron Cup? Professor, I beg of you. Please do not chose me as our house representative. I am utterly serious.

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: What?! Curse you, Professor. I will of course accept, but know that you have damned us all.

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: Oh, thank the goddess. Please be sure to select someone with the confidence to win for us.

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: Incidentally, I have heard there will be a dance competition prior to the ball. Have you chosen a representative yet?

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: I will take part, if you insist.

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: Someone must want to participate. You would do well to find that person.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: Ah, whatever. You look like you're about to say something. Are you considering me as our representative for the White Heron Cup? Heh.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: I was joking. You really couldn't find anyone else?

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: I see. That's a relief.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: But speaking of the ball, isn't there something happening just before it? The White...Heron...something? It sounds like every class needs a representative. Have you picked ours yet?

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: Are you sure you want m-me to do this? I guess I'll just have to do the best I can, then.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: You should pick one of the nobles. They all have experience with this sort of thing.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: The ball is almost here...and the White Heron Cup dance contest. So, Professor, who will be representing our class?

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Me? Uh, sure! Why not? I'll get out there, show off my moves, and drive the ladies wild.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: I get it. No worries, really. I'd rather see a beautiful person dancing instead of some goof like me.

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: While we're on the subject of the ball, what's this I hear about a dance competition? Physical activity isn't my forte, but dancing can be fun! If there's no one else you'd rather select, I'm happy to represent our class.

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: Thanks for having faith in me, Professor! I'll try my best to win!

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: Are you sure? Please let me know if you change your mind!

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: After all, we have the ball to look forward to, and the White Heron Cup before that! Oh, speaking of have you chosen our house representative yet? If not, I'd like to volunteer!

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: Really? That's fantastic! I'll try as hard as anyone's ever tried, you can count on it!

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: Aw, that's too bad. But if you reconsider, you know where to find me!

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Speaking of, I heard that there's going to be a dance competition. Have you sorted out who will represent our class, Professor? It's not me, is it? Please don't say it's me...

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Oh dear... Well, I'll see what I can do, then. On my honor.

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Thank goodness. I don't know the first thing about dancing.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: Considering this recent rash of strange incidents, I wonder if having a ball is really the best idea... And then there's the White Heron Cup. Sheesh. What poor sap are you enlisting to represent our house, Teach?

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: Claude: Me?! Don't be unreasonable, Teach! Ugh... I mean, if I have to make a miracle happen, I guess I'll figure it out...

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: Oh, but first, the White Heron Cup! Who will appear onstage, I wonder? You're choosing a representative for the dance contest, isn't that right? Choose me! I'm a pro!

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: Great! Now that I'm in the spotlight, I'll do anything to win!

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: Aww, I was really getting excited for it. Let me know if you change your mind, huh?

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: From what I hear, the White Heron Cup will be held just prior to the ball. Say no more, Professor. I would consider it an honor to represent our class!

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: You will not regret this choice!

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: By all means, take your time and think it over. But I do assure you, there is no candidate better suited to the task than yours truly.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Apparently there's supposed to be a dance contest too. I think it's called the White Heron Cup. Who's gonna represent our class? I can do it if you haven't picked someone else!

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: You made the right choice, Professor! Everyone's gonna think my moves are hilarious!

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Aww, really? I may not look it, but I'm actually a pretty good dancer.

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: Watching other people dance can be fun though. I've heard people talking about the White Heron Cup. Do you know who will be representing us?

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: Me?! What? No, please! You can't!

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: I think a noble would make for a better choice. Bound to know their way around a ballroom.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: Right... It's the dance this month, isn't it? I can't see how anyone would be much in the mood for dancing, considering... Although I suppose the White Heron Cup does sound pretty fun.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: Uh, you want me to be our representative? I've certainly got a few moves...

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: It would probably be more logical to ask someone who likes dancing in the first place, so I certainly understand.

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: There's a dance contest as well? I see. I'll cheer for our class, of course. So, um... Who will represent our house in the contest?

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: I see, well... Um, I'm sorry. What did you say?

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: I'm sure whoever represents our class will do a fine job. Much better than I could do.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: The ball? Doesn't matter. I don't dance. I might show up for the food though. Not that it's got anything to do with me, but have you picked someone to represent us for the White Heron Cup yet?

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: What? You're asking a peasant to dance? You've got some pretty weird ideas!

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: Well, someone's bound to want to do it. I'm sure we've got a few people with the talent to win too.

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: Have you heard yet about the White Heron Cup? If you have yet to choose a representative, do you mind terribly if I volunteer?

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: Ah, thank you, Professor! I am overcome with joy! Just you wait until my feet touch the ballroom floor!

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: Understood. Ah, well. Either way, I am still so excited about the ball!

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: Well, I suppose we should practice, then. Shall we?

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: How was that? I believe I've improved my technique.

conversation.speaker: Edelgard
conversation.line: Huh... Well, let's practice whenever you can spare the time. Agreed?

conversation.speaker: Hubert
conversation.line: To think I'd be rehearsing my dance moves, of all things. Give me some advice, Professor.

conversation.speaker: Hubert
conversation.line: A little less grotesque now? Maybe.

conversation.speaker: Hubert
conversation.line: All right. But if we want to avoid a tragic accident during the contest, I will need more practice.

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: Professor, uh... Do you know how to dance? I could really use some guidance.

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: You really can do everything! I am envious of you, if you will pardon my frankness.

conversation.speaker: Ferdinand
conversation.line: Fair enough. You do not think I need guidance. You are probably right.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: Professor? Are you here to practice with me for the dance contest?

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: I don't enjoy a bit of this, you know. Entirely too much standing up and moving around for my taste. But if I'm going to do it, I may as well be in it to win.

conversation.speaker: Linhardt
conversation.line: I see... Well, that's just fine by me. There's a book on fishing that I'd like to finish.

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: Hey, Professor! Did you want to practice dancing with me?

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: What did you think? Pretty perfect, right?

conversation.speaker: Caspar
conversation.line: You're probably right. I don't need any more practice. I'm a natural!

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: Professor! Will you give me some dancing lessons?

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: Was that okay? A little reassuring at least? Maybe?

conversation.speaker: Bernadetta
conversation.line: Is this your idea of an education? Clip my wings and toss me off a cliff?!

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: Hey, Professor. You're here to help me practice for the dance contest?

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: How was that? Was my dancing everything you hoped for and more? I certainly enjoyed it. We simply must do it again. Soon.

conversation.speaker: Dorothea
conversation.line: Well, I am terribly talented, agreed. Still, I think I'll practice on my own if you're too busy.

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: I have much to be learned. We will now practice the dancing, OK?

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: I have much more knowledge of Fódlan lance. How is my dancing, Professor?

conversation.speaker: Petra
conversation.line: That is not fortunate. I will have patience.

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: I am in the thick of battle, so battle I must. Will you help me prepare, Professor?

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: How...was that? I perhaps did not offend as much as usual, but...I do not like our chances.

conversation.speaker: Dimitri
conversation.line: I suppose I must practice diligently while I can. On my own. Away from prying eyes.

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: Will you teach me to dance?

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: Was that satisfactory?

conversation.speaker: Dedue
conversation.line: That makes things difficult.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: Here, help me practice my dancing. You forced me into this, so you're going to help me.

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: How did I get roped into this?

conversation.speaker: Felix
conversation.line: Hmph! You irresponsible fiend.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: I've been practicing as best as I can, Professor, but do you think you could give me a little help?

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: Was that all right? I'm completely self-taught, so I really have no idea.

conversation.speaker: Ashe
conversation.line: You really want to leave this all up to me?

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Oh, Professor! I'm glad you're here. I need help figuring out this whole...dancing thing. Mind helping me?

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: One and two and three and four... Got it! I'm pretty good at this.

conversation.speaker: Sylvain
conversation.line: Aw, don't be like that, Professor. You chose me... You should help me win.

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: Oh, Professor? Do you mind watching my dance routine? I would appreciate your honest opinion.

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: How was that? I hope it's good enough to win...

conversation.speaker: Mercedes
conversation.line: I'm so sorry, I didn't realize you were busy. I didn't mean to distract you.

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: Professor! Would you watch me dance really quick? I've been practicing a ton!

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: Mwahaha! Well? What do you think? I'd say I'm pretty great. Wouldn't you?

conversation.speaker: Annette
conversation.line: Oh, do you have really important professor things to do? Well, let me know when you have the time!

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Professor, I admit--I have two left feet when it comes to dancing. Do you have time to give me any pointers?

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: How did I do? Was I awkward? I felt awkward.

conversation.speaker: Ingrid
conversation.line: Perhaps some other time, then. Since you chose me, I'll need your guidance in all this.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: Teach, this is all your doing. Step up and take responsibility. You've got to help me practice my dance moves.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: My legs aren't as unwieldy as before, I think... If I keep this up, I might do not terribly.

conversation.speaker: Claude
conversation.line: You're too busy? Too busy to take responsibility for your actions? Wow. Well, you'd better make time for me before it's too late.

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: Hey, Professor! Care to join me for dance practice?

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: Phew! I don't think we can possibly lose. Just you wait and see.

conversation.speaker: Hilda
conversation.line: What, you've got something better to do than watch me practice?

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: Rehearsals will not be necessary. But, if you insist, I can give you a small taste of what is to come.

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: Well, Professor? Are those not the most exquisitely refined moved you have ever witnessed?

conversation.speaker: Lorenz
conversation.line: I assure you, dancing is fully ingrained in my being. Any further practice would be redundant.

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: Hey, Professor! You want to teach me some winning dance moves?

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: That looked pretty good, right? I think I can win this thing!

conversation.speaker: Raphael
conversation.line: If you think my moves are good enough, then I don't need dance lessons.

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: Professor, can you watch me practice?

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: Is this how you do it? I'm feeling a little unsteady...

conversation.speaker: Ignatz
conversation.line: Professor, don't abandon me in my time of need! Why'd you pick me in the first place?!

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: Professor, can you supervise my dance rehearsal? If I'm going to do this, I want to win it.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: Well? How was I? I figure if I dance with passion and fervor, I'll appear even more mature.

conversation.speaker: Lysithea
conversation.line: You've chosen me, but you won't even bother to help me prepare? That's rather rude, Professor!

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: Did you need something, Professor? I suppose I should p-practice, right?

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: No, no. That's no good. I can't seem to get a feel for it...

conversation.speaker: Marianne
conversation.line: Oh. Very well.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: Professor! Come join me for dance practice!

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: I'm going to have to do this in front of a crowd? I can feel myself going pale already.

conversation.speaker: Leonie
conversation.line: Hey, you're the one who put me up to this! The least you can do is give me a hand!

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: Yes? Do you need me for anything, Professor? I would be happy for some dancing guidance, should you have any!

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: Thank you so much. I am eager to improve my dancing.

conversation.speaker: Flayn
conversation.line: I see. Perhaps soon!

dialogue.speaker: Rhea
dialogue.line: Professor. I have been waiting for you. I am filled with grief at the loss of our most celebrated knight. Jeralt was an ally of many years...and also a dear friend.

dialogue.speaker: Rhea
dialogue.line: It was a long while back. At the time, Jeralt was a soldier of the Kingdom. He was injured in battle, and I saved him just as he was about to perish. That was our first meeting. After that, he became a Knight of Seiros. He gave his all to the service of the church.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Why did he leave the knights?

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: But it had been so long since you last saw him...

dialogue.speaker: Rhea
dialogue.line: He...fell in love with one of the nuns here at Garreg Mach. Their love produced a child...whom she died giving birth to. It was her decision. She weighed her own life against that of her child's and, in the end, implored me to save the child. Your father...never truly accepted that decision. He took the child–took you–and disappeared without warning.

dialogue.speaker: Byleth
dialogue.line: Did I inherit my Crest from my mother?

dialogue.speaker: Alois
dialogue.line: Sorry for the interruption, Lady Rhea. There's something you must hear immediately. A report from the knights patrolling the area...

dialogue.speaker: Rhea
dialogue.line: Very well. Professor, you are dismissed for the day. Please rest and focus only on mending your heart. Understood?

flashback.speaker: Edelgard
flashback.line: Wrong foot, Dimitri! You're supposed to lead with your right!

flashback.speaker: Dimitri
flashback.line: El, the sun's going down! I really oughta be heading home...

battle.speaker: Jeralt
battle.line: The Demonic Beasts were actually students? How can this be...

battle.speaker: Student
battle.line: Thank you! But my friends who couldn't get away... Are they OK?

battle.speaker: Student
battle.line: I was so scared... I'll find a way to repay you, I promise!

battle.speaker: Student
battle.line: Sorry. That was a close one...

battle.speaker: Student
battle.line: Phew... You saved me. Thank you!

battle-talk.speaker: Jeralt
battle-talk.line: Do you really think you can keep going? Don't push yourself too hard. Thinking about what happened in Remire village, it's clear you've gotten the hang of being a leader. Maybe you should have taken command of me too!

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: There you are. Lady Rhea is looking for you, Professor. And after your audience, why don't you join me at the dining hall? You haven't eaten since...since it happened. Have you?

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Forgive me... I suppose it's too soon to try and coax you back into the normal swing of things. As for what happened to Jeralt... I'm so sorry. I'm sorry I couldn't do anything to stop it. Stay here until you've found some peace. I'll cover for you with Lady Rhea and everyone else.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: We'll be waiting for you whenever you're ready to return to us.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: No need to put on a brave face. No one would blame you for taking time for yourself.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: I don't believe it's a sign of strength to just keep going forward no matter what. Taking the time to grieve for those we've lost...there's strength in that too. That's what I think, anyway. That said... It's also important to remember that no matter how sad you are, eventually your tears will dry up. That's when you have to figure out what it is you're living for. Then you can cling to that, with all your might, and start moving forward again.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Four years ago, in Duscur, I experienced the same pain you're feeling now. My father...was the strongest man I knew. Someone I loved and admired deeply. That day, he was killed before my eyes. His head severed clean off. My stepmother, the kindest person I had ever known, left me behind and disappeared into the infernal flames.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Everyone who I considered precious...my family and my closest friends...I couldn't save any of them. Not a single one. Now, the burden of the work they left behind falls on me. I must ensure they have no regrets. That's my duty, as the sole survivor of the tragedy. It's a heavy burden, but accepting it gave me the strength to pick myself up off the ground and start moving again. Start living again.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: Jeralt is gone... So, what will you do now, Professor? What must you do? Look deep in your heart and I'm certain you'll find the answer there...indelible and inescapable.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: I've probably bothered you enough for today, but I have just one more thought to leave you with. Even now, Seteth is gathering the knights to begin a full scale search for the enemy. It may not be right away, but before long they will find their trail.

end.speaker: Dimitri
end.line: No matter what happens or what anyone may say, know that I plan to stand by you, Professor. Through anything. Until the bitter end.

end.speaker: Sothis
end.line: Well? Did you search deep within yourself as he suggested? And did you find yourself some answers? This book is filled with secrets yet unknown. We must return another time to read the rest. Oh, but I have at least figured one thing out. I know now why our fates are intertwined...

end.speaker: Alois
end.line: Ah... Here you are. To think that Captain... that Jeralt would meet his end like that. I hope you know that you were the most important thing in the world to him.

end.speaker: Alois
end.line: He wasn't the most emotional guy. I'm sure expressing his affection wouldn't have come naturally to him. After what's happened, it's up to me now. I, Alois, swear to protect you in the captain's stead.  Sorry. This isn't the time for my blathering. Lady Rhea is looking for you. I came to tell you that. I'll take my leave now.

end.speaker: Sothis
end.line: This book is filled with secrets yet unknown. We must return another time to read the rest. Oh, but I have at least figured one thing out. I know now why our fates are intertwined...

cutscene.speaker: Monica
cutscene.line: Thanks for all your help, sir.

cutscene.speaker: Monica
cutscene.line: You're just a pathetic old man. How dare you get in the way of my brilliant plan...you dog.

cutscene.speaker: Monica
cutscene.line: Thanks for all your help, sir.

cutscene.speaker: Monica
cutscene.line: Huh? What are you doing here?

cutscene.speaker: Thales
cutscene.line: You must survive. Merely because there is a role that I require you to fulfill.

cutscene.speaker: Jeralt
cutscene.line: Sorry. It looks like...I'm going to have to leave you now.

cutscene.speaker: Jeralt
cutscene.line: To think that the first time I saw you cry...your tears would be for me. It's sad, and yet...I'm happy for it. Thank you...kid.
